title: Meghan R. Hutch
text:
My name is Meghan and I am a Ph.D. Candidate studying Biomedical Informatics through Northwestern University’s Driskill Graduate Program.
As a biomedical informatician and public health data scientist, my research broadly focuses on the application of biostatistic and data science methods to derive insights from patient electronic health records. Specifically, my dissertation focuses on developing risk models that can help us better delineate the clinical trajectories of patients with diverse neurologic illnesses.
I am also extremely passionate about mentoring and teaching! I am always happy to meet with students who are new to coding, interested in pursuing higher education, or who just want to talk science and/or collaborate!
When I’m not running code, I can usually be found running miles along Chicago’s beautiful lake shore trails. I also love to paint, read, and explore Chicago and the surrounding midwest region with friends.

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching
During my participation in Northwestern University’s Reflective and Effective Teaching, I designed a course focused on “Methods for reproducibility in biomedical informatics research”. An introductory graduate level course designed to teach students in biomedical informatics or data science degree programs the importance of scientific reproducibility and best coding practices.
The below links comprise my portfolio of teaching materials developed for my envisioned course.

title: Software
text:
Software
Programming Languages: R | Python | SQL | Bash | LaTeX | markdown
Software: R Shiny | Git | Github | quarto | AWS | Biorender


Websites
SOAR: A Spatial transcriptOmics Analysis Resource: Spatial transcriptomics is an expanding set of techniques used to quantify gene expression within specific locations of a tissue sample. Such technology enables a more precise understanding of gene expression within specific cells and the interactions between cells.
I led the website development for a collaborative team effort to deploy a R Shiny application that provides the scientific and research community access to a curated set of 304 spatial transcriptomic datasets with corresponding analyses of 2,785 tissue samples.
